Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2013 03:31PM crazyride43 wrote: Everyone is different, I'm sure, but here was my experience: Just turned 43 when diagnosed and had very regular periods.  After starting A/C had two very heavy and painful periods, then Taxol threw me into chemopause (very wicked hot flashes!).  Then my period came back 3 months later pretty much the same as always.  My acupuncturist said this was a good sign - by body was healing itself after chemo.  Of course I freaked out a little knowing that my cancer was highly ER+.  After rads I started Tamoxifen (10 months ago), and have had a period on a regular basis, although not as predictable as before.  Sometimes 26 days apart, sometimes 40+ days.  Makes planning tricky!  I have also read mixed reviews on getting a period during tamoxifen...on the plus side it's a good thing that the uterine lining is shedding each month, and on the down side I am still producing a lot of estrogen.  My MO tells me not to worry, that the tamox is doing it's job no matter what estrogen is being produced. Wishing you the best possible experience through all of this.  Feel free to PM me since you are having the exact same treatment as me and we are about the same age!

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2012 04:48PM crazyride43 wrote: roadwarrior, I had 4 dose dense AC and 3 out of 4 dose dense Taxol.  I didn't get the last Taxol due to worsening neuropathy.  At the time my toes were pretty numb, my legs felt weak and I was having trouble doing things like typing because my fingers were really sore.  My MO was very clear that I had already received the majority of the benefit from the Taxol after 3 treatments, and that my hormone positive cancer would benefit most from the Tamoxifen.  She was also very clear that she wouldn't give me the last treatment because she didn't want to leave me with a permanent disability.  Now, after 14 weeks, the neuropathy is much better.  Not gone completely, but it doesn't hamper any daily activities and I feel confident it will keep improving.  My acupuncturist also feels really confident that all my side effects will resolve. Despite what is now mild neuropathy, I am still glad I had at least 3 of the Taxol treatments.  Even though my nodes were negative, my tumor was large and I was considered "young" at 43, which is why I think maximum chemo was recommended.  I do feel like any little cancer cells that had escaped and were floating around got well zapped.  Many people don't seem to get any neuropathy, and if you do start getting symptoms you can always stop the treatment. Best of luck with your decision - nothing is easy in this whole process, that's for sure!

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 11:19AM crazyride43 wrote: Kathie, this is so hard and so personal.  Some women don't have a choice, so I guess it's a good thing that you at least have both as options?  I was in the same boat in January 2012, and ended up deciding on a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy after chemo first to shrink my rather large tumor.  The chemo did it's job and the tumor was pretty much all gone by the time I had surgery.  I was very lucky to have no cancer found in my two sentinel nodes, and had a second revision lumpectomy surgery (very minor) to ensure big, clean margins around where my surgeon took out the remaining cancer (first surgery had clean margins, she just wanted them bigger!).  Then I had 6 weeks of radiation to "sterilize" the breast and node area and take care of anything else that might be lurking.  Rads were tiring and my skin got really pink and sore, but just a few weeks later things were much better.  Now I am on Tamoxifen, which also reduces my chances of recurrence, and I haven't had a lot of side effects.   When I was first diagnosed, I wanted a mastectomy to just get this cancer producing body part off me!  It was a very emotional response to a very scary situation where I felt so out of control.  What I have since learned is that no matter how hard we research all these decisions and try to assess the odds, there are factors we just can't control no matter what.  For example, I know some women choose mastectomy to avoid radiation, but sometimes after surgery rads are still recommended.  My surgeon (who I adore and trust completely) really helped me understand that the stats are virtually the same for a successful lumpectomy + rads, and encouraged me to try to conserve my breast.  She really felt I would have a great outcome, and she was right.  I realized that I was lucky to have amazing medical professionals doing their best to get me well again, and that I needed to trust them.  My left breast is a little smaller and perkier now, but the average person would never know I had anything done even if they looked closely!  If I have a recurrence at some point in the future, I will probably have a mastectomy and I know the rads I have already had may affect my reconstruction options.  I am focusing on the fact that there is a very good chance that I will never need to face that decision, and for now I'm glad to still have both my breasts at 44 years old.  Because of the density of my breasts, I had an MRI at diagnosis and also after chemo, and will have MRI's every year as follow up.  They are much more sensitive than mammograms and I am hopeful they will detect any abnormalities in there.  I know how hard this decision is.  I even let my family and work know that I was having a mastectomy before changing my mind at the 11th hour.  It has to be whatever decision feels right for you.  Knowledge is power...speak to people you trust, and get as many medical opinions as you need to feel informed about your decision.  There is no reason you should feel like you need to make such a big decision based very little information.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2013 10:54AM crazyride43 wrote: I had AC-T neoadjuvant treatment also, and had a node biopsy prior to starting chemo.  Like you, the radiologist had a very hard time finding any nodes that looked mildly suspicious, and ended up doing a biopsy on one that was just slightly thicker than the others.  Even at the time, he didn't think it was cancerous.  I honestly think my surgeon asked for the node biopsy for my peace of mind, not for staging.  My understanding is that when they do the sentinel node biopsy after chemo, they can tell if there was once cancer in the node even if it's now gone. My node biopsy was uncomfortable, but not painful, and nowhere near as difficult as my original breast biopsy.  It was also negative for cancer, which did give me a little peace of mind. Even though I am highly ER+ and PR+, the AC-T chemo completely wiped out my 4cm tumor, allowing for a lumpectomy.  My left breast is now slightly smaller than the right, but other than that no-one could ever tell that I have had anything done at all. Wishing you the best whatever path you choose.

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 03:41PM crazyride43 wrote: Melmcbee, I felt exactly the way you did until about a month ago.  I started out at least 20 pounds overweight, and then gained 10 more pounds over the holidays and right after my diagnosis (emotional eating!).  I actually managed to keep my weight steady throughout chemo, mainly due to pushing myself to walk as much as possible.  It wasn't even for weight reasons at the time - my MO and BS both told me that women who exercised during chemo seemed to do much better.  So even if I could only walk for 10 minutes, my husband would always encourage me to go.  Then it all went to heck when I couldn't exercise for the next 3 months through my two surgeries and radiation, and that's when I gained yet another 10 pounds.  Ugh!  So I was dreading starting Tamoxifen having heard all the weight gain stories.  The good news I want to share with you is that as soon as I had some energy back I started a fitness and healthy eating program and have already lost 10 pounds in a month, and that's while on Tamox.  I still have 30 pounds to go, but I already feel so much better, and very encouraged to know this weight isn't going to hang around forever!  I don't have any magic formula except for the usual eat less exercise more philosophy.  It has really helped me to log my daily food intake in an online program myfitnesspal so i can realy keep track of my calories, fat etc.  I try to keep to around 1300-1400 cals, with at least 100g protein, and less than 40g fat.  I also try to eat something small every 3 hours (with protein if possible), and make sure any carbs are things like brown rice, oatmeal, sprouted wheat bread, fruit and veggies.  for exercise, I'm still walking with my husband 3 - 4 times per week, and then I also do two more intense workouts with some weight training (30 mins) and elliptical machine (30 mins).  If anyone had told me I would be doing all of this a month ago, I would have said they were CRAZY!  But I really do feel stronger and much more able to focus on my health now. To give you a sense of the timing, I had my last dose dense Taxol on April 26th and my last surgery was July 5th.  Rads didn't finish until about 3 weeks ago.  There is no way I could have started my fitness and diet program during that time.  Just like you, I was pretty depressed about my weight gain and couldn't see a light at the end of the tunnel, but I promise you it does come.  Please be kind to yourself and patient and remember that your most important job right now is to fight cancer.  My acupunturist told me that having a healthy appetite during treatment was a good sign, because it meant my body wanted nutrients to stay strong.  I also thought it was the steroids...but that excuse ran out during surgery and rads LOL!  So his explanation made me feel good, like my body was fighting and doing what it was supposed to do to rebuild after chemo. You are doing great, and this too shall pass once you are through treatments!

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2013 11:32AM crazyride43 wrote: I did chemo before surgery, and started my first chemo treatment within days of my appointment with my MO.  I feel like they wanted me to start as soon as possible, so that anything lurking throughout my body would get blasted.  I do think it's common to treat larger tumors with neoadjuvant chemo, to both shrink the tumor for better surgical outcomes, but also to see clearly whether the chemo is working on your particular type of tumor.  At first I just wanted the tumor out...I now know that's a common response.  I am really glad my medical team helped me decide on chemo first.  There was something so encouraging about feeling my 4-5cm tumor shrink after each treatment, and knowing that the entire thing was no longer visible on my pre-surgery MRI.  I also think they were very surprised that with such a large tumor I didn't have any cancer in my nodes...I guess I have what they call a "lazy" tumor, so don't be discouraged because of the size. Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 04:47AM crazyride43 wrote: Percy, my BC breast was already a little smaller than the other to start with, so this was also my concern.  There was some initial "shrinkage", but not sure whether it was from of the amount of breast removed with the lumpectomy, the radiation, or both.  By the time I was a few months out from rads, my two breasts were distinctly different (at least to me!)...one a full D and the other a C and a lot more perky.  I have considered reconstruction which would be covered by insurance, but the advice I have received from several docs is that the risks might outweigh the benefits and the scarring from a reduction and lift is considerable.  My doctors keep assuring me that I look great, and they see a lot of breasts!  Like you I look fine in clothes, so the only person that really notices the size difference is me, when I'm naked in front of the mirror.  My husband says he can't tell unless I really point it out. He doesn't want me to have the surgery.  It's mostly annoying for getting a bra that fits properly because one side has a muffin top while the other side is barely filling the cup, but I have found some soft stretchy bra's that are supportive and minimize this issue (called Warner's Friday bra).  In terms of weight loss, I have both lost 10 lbs and and then gained them back again since rads and haven't noticed a big difference i.e. the size difference and perkiness difference stays about the same. Hopefully the shrinkage you are seeing will stay about where it is now.   And as to whether a new man will find you appealing with slightly lopsided breasts, my experience is that men don't always notice these things or care about them the same way we do.  They are just happy to have a real, warm, affectionate woman to be with!  Remember they are not perfect either...they may have receding hair or a little extra padding in the middle that they are self conscious about.  I try to focus on doing things that help me feel good about myself.  Your confidence and shining, positive personality are always what's most appealing!

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2014 12:10PM crazyride43 wrote: Minus two, I used tea tree oil on my nails every night during chemo and for a few months afterwards.  Just painted it around each cuticle with a q-tip.  It smells pretty awful, but my hubby got used to it and so did I!  I also slathered on the healthy hoof lotion.  I did have a few black lines and my nails ached during Taxol, but I never lost one or had any lifting or fungus.  I also iced my finger and toe nails (as much as I could stand!) during Taxol infusions, and always had on nail hardening polish.  I still take biotin, and my hair and nails have never been more healthy.  Not sure what combo of oil/lotion/icing/polish/biotin saved my nails, but I am super happy that they are in good shape.  Cancer treatments sure do take a lot out of us, so it's nice to have these small victories wherever we can get them!

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 08:25AM crazyride43 wrote: Bob,  I was treated at Dana Farber, and now that I know so much more I really believe the skill of the surgeon is critical for optimal medical and cosmetic outcomes with a lumpectomy and SNB procedure.  You want someone who focuses on breast surgery, has done these procedures many times, and that you trust completely.  My DF surgeon did such an excellent job that no-one would be able to find my lumpectomy incision if they didn't know where to look.  I also needed a re-excision for clean margins, and she went back in through the same incision and it looks no different.  The rest of my DF medical team all describe her as "an artist and truly gifted breast surgeon", and that's what you want for your wife.  Feel free to PM me.  I can't recommend DF any more highly.  They are experts.  I am sure there are some wonderful local surgeons that would do an excellent job, but with DF (or any major cancer center) you will also get the expertise of an entire, cutting edge team and network reviewing your wife's case every step of the way.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 12:20PM crazyride43 wrote: Hi Pamelahope.  I have a very similar diagnosis and also went through DD A/C and Taxol.  The good news is that I am 11 weeks out from my last Taxol and I am back to 90% in terms of energy and doing all the things I usually do.  I wish I could tell you I didn't get any neuropathy, but I did get some even though I was religiously taking B6, L-Glutamine and ALC.  I also iced my fingers and toes during infusions and sucked on ice (I now have an aversion to ice LOL!).  I am not sure if any of it really made a difference, but I always tell myself it could have been so much worse!  Here is the rundown of my experience with DD Taxol:  - Felt pretty good for the day or two afterwards, and then got pretty bad leg pain.  Almost like restless legs, just couldn't get comfortable at all.  Mt MO told me those leg pains and the leg "weakness" feeling were neuropathy.  My toes also started feeling sensitive in closed shoes and my heels ached.  I especially noticed the toe neuropathy in bed with covers on...they would press down on my toes and it just felt plain weird.  Not pain, more like pressure and over-sensitivity. - After battling the constipation on A/C, I had the opposite issue with Taxol.  Not bad, but certainly didn't need all my prunes anymore!  My taste buds were also in great shape and I ate anything in sight! - I first started really noticing the neuropathy in my fingers because I type a lot for work.  It feels weird, sort of like you have bruises on the end of your fingers.  It also felt like I might rip off a fingernail if I opened a soda can.  Very sensitive.  For the first two treatments, I would feel this and then it would get better before the next treatment.  The 3rd Taxol definitely was the worst for me.  I would almost fall down when I got up from sitting, because my legs were just weak.  That really scared me, but it didn't last for long and I haven't experienced that again! - I did get random rashes and itchiness.  I had a barely visible rash on my face and chest for weeks after Taxol, and only recently noticed that it was completely gone. So now, 11 weeks out, I do still have some lingering neuropathy in my fingers and toes but it seems to be getting better all the time, and doesn't really limit me in any way.  My toes are much less noticable than my fingers because of the typing.  As I am typing this, I am favoring my right pointer finger because it's a little sore today and the nail has looked like it might start lifting.  After keeping my nails in good shape this whole time, I don't want to lose one now!  I have been getting acupuncture, and hope it's helping! I didn't experience any hair re-growth while on DD Taxol, and also lost 100% of my eyelashes and brows.  They both grew back very quickly about 6 weeks later.  My hair is now about and inch long and growing like crazy.  I go without a hat sometimes and it doesn't look very stylish, but I'm happy to have any hair!  Hope this helps.  I know many ladies don't get any neuropathy at all, and you might be one of them!  Main message is that even though I did get mild neuropathy, Taxol shrunk my tumor down to almost nothing so I am glad I had it.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2012 05:08PM crazyride43 wrote: I am more of a reader than a poster (love all the advice and sisterhood here - thank you!), but wanted to jump in with a great tip my RO gave me to stop my bra rubbing and avoid staining clothes.  I cut up some old, soft t-shirts into rectangles, and then place the soft cotton rectangle over my lotioned breast and underarm area, then put on my soft bra over the top (I have a Warner's "Friday bra" with no underwire - great support!).  It takes a little while to arrange everything so it's not bunched up under my bra, but then it's comfortable for the rest of the day at work.  I am only halfway through rads, so not sure if this will still be comfortable up until the end.  So far, it has allowed me to wear all my regular clothing with no staining issues at all. Another thing I have been using is boiron calendula first aid ointment.  I use it on my nipple and in the crease under my breast, and it greatly decreases redness and sensitivity.  I love calendula everything, and also use weleda calendula baby cream and lotion! Wishing everyone here minimal side effects on their rads journey!

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 10:38AM crazyride43 wrote: Sherri, I am so sorry you are facing this diagnosis.  It's wonderful news that it was caught early and you have options.  I was also given the option of mastectomy vs lumpectomy + radiation.  My surgeon was very clear that the survival statistics are the same with both, with a slightly higher local recurrence rate for lumpectomy.  I chose the lumpectomy + radiation, and also had a sentinel node biopsy.  I had to go in for a second surgery for bigger margins, but was glad because that just confirmed that there was no more cancer lurking.  I had a 2cm+ tumor, so was worried about deformity, but my surgeon did an amazing job and I can't even see the scar now.  I also had a good experience with rads - definitely got sore and red, but no skin breakdown and now my breast looks pretty much the same as it did before all of this, just a little smaller and perkier.  I started weight training (gentle!) with help from a trainer about three months after my surgery once radiation was done.  I also saw a physical therapist to learn stretching techniques for range of motion and to be evaluated for LE (which I thankfully don't have at this stage).  I am still thinking of getting a sleeve for prevention now that my weight training is getting more intense, but I haven't experienced anything but positive effects from weight training. Feel free to PM me with any questions.  Where you are right now is one of the most difficult stages of this whole thing, and I remember all those feelings of being overwhelmed and confused and scared.  Just one year later it's already starting to feel like a distant memory.  You can do this!

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 09:08PM crazyride43 wrote: Truffles, I had the exact same chemo, and I did keep working but thank goodness I was able to create a very flexible work schedule.  I would say I worked on average 25 - 30 hours per week, but at least half of those hours were from my couch at home, and I was down for the count at least 3 - 4 days after each chemo.  I probably could have dragged myself to work on day three, but I would have really struggled to put in 10 hours and be focused, and I am so glad I had the option to rest.  In the beginning I really thought I would be able to "tough it out" and keep going at my usual pace because I have always had a lot of stamina and was in perfect health (aside from having BC of course!).  I was really so clueless about the freight train that was getting ready to hit me!  I had pretty minimal side effects from chemo (relatively speaking!), but my body still went through all kinds of crazy changes and I was also very mentally and emotionally fatigued.  Not every day, but it was impossible to predict when I would suddenly "run out of gas" and need to rest, rest, rest.  It sounds like you have the financial ability to do this, along with the option to take a year of leave, maintain benefits and return to the exact same position.  Even though I love my job, I would have jumped all over that option, so I say DO IT!!!  Your body and health will definitely thank you for it!

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 09:16AM crazyride43 wrote: Ahowe I'm so sorry to hear about your daughter's diagnosis so soon after your own.  This disease is so insidious.  I am also large breasted and had some extreme redness and peeling under my breast and a constant burning sensation.  I used boiron calendula cream (there is also an ointment) for healing because it was all natural, and then a mix of aquafor and 5% lidocaine for the pain. My RO prescribed the lidocaine ointment and it was a godsend for all the extra sore spots.  I also got some non stick dressings from my nurse that were coated in aquafor.  I would place those over the really sore and red areas after adding some extra aquafor and lidocaine, then cover with another padded dressing, and that would allow me to wear a very soft bra (which then kept my breast from sagging down too much over the sore area under my breast).  Rads finished for me just under three weeks ago, and almost all the discomfort is gone and everything is healed up and looking pretty much normal again. Wishing you speedy healing, a great outcome for your daughter, and sending you both a hug.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2012 08:59AM crazyride43 wrote: jojo, I also had chemo first - dose dense AC + Taxol - to shrink the tumor and allow for a lumpectomy.  I had a great complete clinical response (no sign of tumor on MRI before surgery), and the final pathology showed only very small amounts of risidual cancer cells.  My surgeon was very pleased with the results, considering hormone positive cancer doesn't always respond as well to chemo.  For me, I was so glad to have the motivation of a shrinking tumor to help get me through chemo.  No matter what surgery you have afterwards, there is something very affirming about watching the cancer "go away" more and more after each treatment.  Best of luck with your treatments!
